name: CYMBELINE
line: ACT I

name: CYMBELINE
line: SCENE I. Elsinore. A platform before the castle.

name: CYMBELINE
line: FRANCISCO at his post. Enter to him BERNARDO

name: BERNARDO
line: Who's there?

name: FRANCISCO
line: Nay, answer me: stand, and unfold yourself.

name: BERNARDO
line: Long live the king!

name: FRANCISCO
line: Bernardo?

name: BERNARDO
line: He.

name: FRANCISCO
line: You come most carefully upon your hour.

name: BERNARDO
line: 'Tis now struck twelve, get thee to bed, Francisco.

name: FRANCISCO
line: For this relief much thanks: 'tis bitter cold,

name: FRANCISCO
line: And I am sick at heart.

name: BERNARDO
line: Have you had quiet guard?

name: FRANCISCO
line: Not a mouse stirring.

name: BERNARDO
line: Well, good night.

name: BERNARDO
line: If you do meet Horatio and Marcellus,

name: BERNARDO
line: The rivals of my watch, bid them make haste.

name: FRANCISCO
line: I think I hear them. Stand, ho! Who's there?

name: FRANCISCO
line: Enter HORATIO and MARCELLUS

name: HORATIO
line: Friends to this ground.

name: MARCELLUS
line: And liegemen to the Dane.

name: FRANCISCO
line: Give you good night.

name: MARCELLUS
line: O, farewell, honest soldier:

name: MARCELLUS
line: Who hath relieved you?

name: FRANCISCO
line: Bernardo has my place.

name: FRANCISCO
line: Give you good night.

name: FRANCISCO
line: Exit

name: MARCELLUS
line: Holla! Bernardo!

name: BERNARDO
line: Say,

name: BERNARDO
line: What, is Horatio there?

name: HORATIO
line: A piece of him.

name: BERNARDO
line: Welcome, Horatio: welcome, good Marcellus.

name: MARCELLUS
line: What, has this thing appear'd again to-night?

name: BERNARDO
line: I have seen nothing.

name: MARCELLUS
line: Horatio says 'tis but our fantasy,

name: MARCELLUS
line: And will not let belief take hold of him

name: MARCELLUS
line: Touching this dreaded sight, twice seen of us:

name: MARCELLUS
line: Therefore I have entreated him along

name: MARCELLUS
line: With us to watch the minutes of this night,

name: MARCELLUS
line: That if again this apparition come,

name: MARCELLUS
line: He may approve our eyes and speak to it.

name: HORATIO
line: Tush, tush, 'twill not appear.

name: BERNARDO
line: Sit down awhile,

name: BERNARDO
line: And let us once again assail your ears,

name: BERNARDO
line: That are so fortified against our story

name: BERNARDO
line: What we have two nights seen.

name: HORATIO
line: Well, sit we down,

name: HORATIO
line: And let us hear Bernardo speak of this.

name: BERNARDO
line: Last night of all,

name: BERNARDO
line: When yond same star that's westward from the pole

name: BERNARDO
line: Had made his course to illume that part of heaven

name: BERNARDO
line: Where now it burns, Marcellus and myself,

name: BERNARDO
line: The bell then beating one,--

name: BERNARDO
line: Enter Ghost

name: MARCELLUS
line: Peace, break thee off, look, where it comes again!

name: BERNARDO
line: In the same figure, like the king that's dead.

name: MARCELLUS
line: Thou art a scholar, speak to it, Horatio.

name: BERNARDO
line: Looks it not like the king?  mark it, Horatio.

name: HORATIO
line: Most like: it harrows me with fear and wonder.

name: BERNARDO
line: It would be spoke to.

name: MARCELLUS
line: Question it, Horatio.

name: HORATIO
line: What art thou that usurp'st this time of night,

name: HORATIO
line: Together with that fair and warlike form

name: HORATIO
line: In which the majesty of buried Denmark

name: HORATIO
line: Did sometimes march? by heaven I charge thee, speak!

name: MARCELLUS
line: It is offended.

name: BERNARDO
line: See, it stalks away!

name: HORATIO
line: Stay! speak, speak! I charge thee, speak!

name: HORATIO
line: Exit Ghost

name: MARCELLUS
line: 'Tis gone, and will not answer.

name: BERNARDO
line: How now, Horatio! you tremble and look pale:

name: BERNARDO
line: Is not this something more than fantasy?

name: BERNARDO
line: What think you on't?

name: HORATIO
line: Before my God, I might not this believe

name: HORATIO
line: Without the sensible and true avouch

name: HORATIO
line: Of mine own eyes.

name: MARCELLUS
line: Is it not like the king?

name: HORATIO
line: As thou art to thyself:

name: HORATIO
line: Such was the very armour he had on

name: HORATIO
line: When he the ambitious Norway combated,

name: HORATIO
line: So frown'd he once, when, in an angry parle,

name: HORATIO
line: He smote the sledded Polacks on the ice.

name: HORATIO
line: 'Tis strange.

name: MARCELLUS
line: Thus twice before, and jump at this dead hour,

name: MARCELLUS
line: With martial stalk hath he gone by our watch.

name: HORATIO
line: In what particular thought to work I know not,

name: HORATIO
line: But in the gross and scope of my opinion,

name: HORATIO
line: This bodes some strange eruption to our state.

name: MARCELLUS
line: Good now, sit down, and tell me, he that knows,

name: MARCELLUS
line: Why this same strict and most observant watch

name: MARCELLUS
line: So nightly toils the subject of the land,

name: MARCELLUS
line: And why such daily cast of brazen cannon,

name: MARCELLUS
line: And foreign mart for implements of war,

name: MARCELLUS
line: Why such impress of shipwrights, whose sore task

name: MARCELLUS
line: Does not divide the Sunday from the week,

name: MARCELLUS
line: What might be toward, that this sweaty haste

name: MARCELLUS
line: Doth make the night joint-labourer with the day:

name: MARCELLUS
line: Who is't that can inform me?

name: HORATIO
line: That can I,

name: HORATIO
line: At least, the whisper goes so. Our last king,

name: HORATIO
line: Whose image even but now appear'd to us,

name: HORATIO
line: Was, as you know, by Fortinbras of Norway,

name: HORATIO
line: Thereto prick'd on by a most emulate pride,

name: HORATIO
line: Dared to the combat, in which our valiant Hamlet--

name: HORATIO
line: For so this side of our known world esteem'd him--

name: HORATIO
line: Did slay this Fortinbras, who by a seal'd compact,

name: HORATIO
line: Well ratified by law and heraldry,

name: HORATIO
line: Did forfeit, with his life, all those his lands

name: HORATIO
line: Which he stood seized of, to the conqueror:

name: HORATIO
line: Against the which, a moiety competent

name: HORATIO
line: Was gaged by our king, which had return'd

name: HORATIO
line: To the inheritance of Fortinbras,

name: HORATIO
line: Had he been vanquisher, as, by the same covenant,

name: HORATIO
line: And carriage of the article design'd,

name: HORATIO
line: His fell to Hamlet. Now, sir, young Fortinbras,

name: HORATIO
line: Of unimproved mettle hot and full,

name: HORATIO
line: Hath in the skirts of Norway here and there

name: HORATIO
line: Shark'd up a list of lawless resolutes,

name: HORATIO
line: For food and diet, to some enterprise

name: HORATIO
line: That hath a stomach in't, which is no other--

name: HORATIO
line: As it doth well appear unto our state--

name: HORATIO
line: But to recover of us, by strong hand

name: HORATIO
line: And terms compulsatory, those foresaid lands

name: HORATIO
line: So by his father lost: and this, I take it,

name: HORATIO
line: Is the main motive of our preparations,

name: HORATIO
line: The source of this our watch and the chief head

name: HORATIO
line: Of this post-haste and romage in the land.

name: BERNARDO
line: I think it be no other but e'en so:

name: BERNARDO
line: Well may it sort that this portentous figure

name: BERNARDO
line: Comes armed through our watch, so like the king

name: BERNARDO
line: That was and is the question of these wars.

name: HORATIO
line: A mote it is to trouble the mind's eye.

name: HORATIO
line: In the most high and palmy state of Rome,

name: HORATIO
line: A little ere the mightiest Julius fell,

name: HORATIO
line: The graves stood tenantless and the sheeted dead

name: HORATIO
line: Did squeak and gibber in the Roman streets:

name: HORATIO
line: As stars with trains of fire and dews of blood,

name: HORATIO
line: Disasters in the sun, and the moist star

name: HORATIO
line: Upon whose influence Neptune's empire stands

name: HORATIO
line: Was sick almost to doomsday with eclipse:

name: HORATIO
line: And even the like precurse of fierce events,

name: HORATIO
line: As harbingers preceding still the fates

name: HORATIO
line: And prologue to the omen coming on,

name: HORATIO
line: Have heaven and earth together demonstrated

name: HORATIO
line: Unto our climatures and countrymen.--

name: HORATIO
line: But soft, behold! lo, where it comes again!

name: HORATIO
line: Re-enter Ghost

name: HORATIO
line: I'll cross it, though it blast me. Stay, illusion!

name: HORATIO
line: If thou hast any sound, or use of voice,

name: HORATIO
line: Speak to me:

name: HORATIO
line: If there be any good thing to be done,

name: HORATIO
line: That may to thee do ease and grace to me,

name: HORATIO
line: Speak to me:

name: HORATIO
line: Cock crows

name: HORATIO
line: If thou art privy to thy country's fate,

name: HORATIO
line: Which, happily, foreknowing may avoid, O, speak!

name: HORATIO
line: Or if thou hast uphoarded in thy life

name: HORATIO
line: Extorted treasure in the womb of earth,

name: HORATIO
line: For which, they say, you spirits oft walk in death,

name: HORATIO
line: Speak of it: stay, and speak! Stop it, Marcellus.

name: MARCELLUS
line: Shall I strike at it with my partisan?

name: HORATIO
line: Do, if it will not stand.

name: BERNARDO
line: 'Tis here!

name: HORATIO
line: 'Tis here!

name: MARCELLUS
line: 'Tis gone!

name: MARCELLUS
line: Exit Ghost

name: MARCELLUS
line: We do it wrong, being so majestical,

name: MARCELLUS
line: To offer it the show of violence,

name: MARCELLUS
line: For it is, as the air, invulnerable,

name: MARCELLUS
line: And our vain blows malicious mockery.

name: BERNARDO
line: It was about to speak, when the cock crew.

name: HORATIO
line: And then it started like a guilty thing

name: HORATIO
line: Upon a fearful summons. I have heard,

name: HORATIO
line: The cock, that is the trumpet to the morn,

name: HORATIO
line: Doth with his lofty and shrill-sounding throat

name: HORATIO
line: Awake the god of day, and, at his warning,

name: HORATIO
line: Whether in sea or fire, in earth or air,

name: HORATIO
line: The extravagant and erring spirit hies

name: HORATIO
line: To his confine: and of the truth herein

name: HORATIO
line: This present object made probation.

name: MARCELLUS
line: It faded on the crowing of the cock.

name: MARCELLUS
line: Some say that ever 'gainst that season comes

name: MARCELLUS
line: Wherein our Saviour's birth is celebrated,

name: MARCELLUS
line: The bird of dawning singeth all night long:

name: MARCELLUS
line: And then, they say, no spirit dares stir abroad,

name: MARCELLUS
line: The nights are wholesome, then no planets strike,

name: MARCELLUS
line: No fairy takes, nor witch hath power to charm,

name: MARCELLUS
line: So hallow'd and so gracious is the time.

name: HORATIO
line: So have I heard and do in part believe it.

name: HORATIO
line: But, look, the morn, in russet mantle clad,

name: HORATIO
line: Walks o'er the dew of yon high eastward hill:

name: HORATIO
line: Break we our watch up, and by my advice,

name: HORATIO
line: Let us impart what we have seen to-night

name: HORATIO
line: Unto young Hamlet, for, upon my life,

name: HORATIO
line: This spirit, dumb to us, will speak to him.

name: HORATIO
line: Do you consent we shall acquaint him with it,

name: HORATIO
line: As needful in our loves, fitting our duty?

name: MARCELLUS
line: Let's do't, I pray, and I this morning know

name: MARCELLUS
line: Where we shall find him most conveniently.

name: MARCELLUS
line: Exeunt

name: MARCELLUS
line: SCENE II. A room of state in the castle.

name: MARCELLUS
line: Enter KING CLAUDIUS, QUEEN GERTRUDE, HAMLET,  POLONIUS, LAERTES, VOLTIMAND, CORNELIUS, Lords, and Attendants

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Though yet of Hamlet our dear brother's death

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: The memory be green, and that it us befitted

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: To bear our hearts in grief and our whole kingdom

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: To be contracted in one brow of woe,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Yet so far hath discretion fought with nature

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: That we with wisest sorrow think on him,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Together with remembrance of ourselves.

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Therefore our sometime sister, now our queen,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: The imperial jointress to this warlike state,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Have we, as 'twere with a defeated joy,--

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: With an auspicious and a dropping eye,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: With mirth in funeral and with dirge in marriage,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: In equal scale weighing delight and dole,--

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Taken to wife: nor have we herein barr'd

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Your better wisdoms, which have freely gone

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: With this affair along. For all, our thanks.

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Now follows, that you know, young Fortinbras,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Holding a weak supposal of our worth,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Or thinking by our late dear brother's death

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Our state to be disjoint and out of frame,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Colleagued with the dream of his advantage,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: He hath not fail'd to pester us with message,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Importing the surrender of those lands

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Lost by his father, with all bonds of law,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: To our most valiant brother. So much for him.

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Now for ourself and for this time of meeting:

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Thus much the business is: we have here writ

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: To Norway, uncle of young Fortinbras,--

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Who, impotent and bed-rid, scarcely hears

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Of this his nephew's purpose,--to suppress

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: His further gait herein, in that the levies,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: The lists and full proportions, are all made

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Out of his subject: and we here dispatch

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: You, good Cornelius, and you, Voltimand,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: For bearers of this greeting to old Norway,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Giving to you no further personal power

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: To business with the king, more than the scope

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Of these delated articles allow.

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Farewell, and let your haste commend your duty.

name: VOLTIMAND
line: In that and all things will we show our duty.

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: We doubt it nothing: heartily farewell.

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Exeunt VOLTIMAND and CORNELIUS

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: And now, Laertes, what's the news with you?

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: You told us of some suit, what is't, Laertes?

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: You cannot speak of reason to the Dane,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: And loose your voice: what wouldst thou beg, Laertes,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: That shall not be my offer, not thy asking?

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: The head is not more native to the heart,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: The hand more instrumental to the mouth,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Than is the throne of Denmark to thy father.

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: What wouldst thou have, Laertes?

name: LAERTES
line: My dread lord,

name: LAERTES
line: Your leave and favour to return to France,

name: LAERTES
line: From whence though willingly I came to Denmark,

name: LAERTES
line: To show my duty in your coronation,

name: LAERTES
line: Yet now, I must confess, that duty done,

name: LAERTES
line: My thoughts and wishes bend again toward France

name: LAERTES
line: And bow them to your gracious leave and pardon.

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Have you your father's leave? What says Polonius?

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: He hath, my lord, wrung from me my slow leave

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: By laboursome petition, and at last

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Upon his will I seal'd my hard consent:

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: I do beseech you, give him leave to go.

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Take thy fair hour, Laertes, time be thine,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: And thy best graces spend it at thy will!

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: But now, my cousin Hamlet, and my son,--

name: HAMLET
line: [Aside]  A little more than kin, and less than kind.

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: How is it that the clouds still hang on you?

name: HAMLET
line: Not so, my lord, I am too much i' the sun.

name: QUEEN GERTRUDE
line: Good Hamlet, cast thy nighted colour off,

name: QUEEN GERTRUDE
line: And let thine eye look like a friend on Denmark.

name: QUEEN GERTRUDE
line: Do not for ever with thy vailed lids

name: QUEEN GERTRUDE
line: Seek for thy noble father in the dust:

name: QUEEN GERTRUDE
line: Thou know'st 'tis common, all that lives must die,

name: QUEEN GERTRUDE
line: Passing through nature to eternity.

name: HAMLET
line: Ay, madam, it is common.

name: QUEEN GERTRUDE
line: If it be,

name: QUEEN GERTRUDE
line: Why seems it so particular with thee?

name: HAMLET
line: Seems, madam! nay it is, I know not 'seems.'

name: HAMLET
line: 'Tis not alone my inky cloak, good mother,

name: HAMLET
line: Nor customary suits of solemn black,

name: HAMLET
line: Nor windy suspiration of forced breath,

name: HAMLET
line: No, nor the fruitful river in the eye,

name: HAMLET
line: Nor the dejected 'havior of the visage,

name: HAMLET
line: Together with all forms, moods, shapes of grief,

name: HAMLET
line: That can denote me truly: these indeed seem,

name: HAMLET
line: For they are actions that a man might play:

name: HAMLET
line: But I have that within which passeth show,

name: HAMLET
line: These but the trappings and the suits of woe.

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: 'Tis sweet and commendable in your nature, Hamlet,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: To give these mourning duties to your father:

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: But, you must know, your father lost a father,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: That father lost, lost his, and the survivor bound

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: In filial obligation for some term

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: To do obsequious sorrow: but to persever

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: In obstinate condolement is a course

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Of impious stubbornness, 'tis unmanly grief,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: It shows a will most incorrect to heaven,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: A heart unfortified, a mind impatient,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: An understanding simple and unschool'd:

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: For what we know must be and is as common

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: As any the most vulgar thing to sense,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Why should we in our peevish opposition

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Take it to heart? Fie! 'tis a fault to heaven,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: A fault against the dead, a fault to nature,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: To reason most absurd: whose common theme

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Is death of fathers, and who still hath cried,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: From the first corse till he that died to-day,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: 'This must be so.' We pray you, throw to earth

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: This unprevailing woe, and think of us

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: As of a father: for let the world take note,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: You are the most immediate to our throne,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: And with no less nobility of love

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Than that which dearest father bears his son,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Do I impart toward you. For your intent

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: In going back to school in Wittenberg,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: It is most retrograde to our desire:

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: And we beseech you, bend you to remain

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Here, in the cheer and comfort of our eye,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Our chiefest courtier, cousin, and our son.

name: QUEEN GERTRUDE
line: Let not thy mother lose her prayers, Hamlet:

name: QUEEN GERTRUDE
line: I pray thee, stay with us, go not to Wittenberg.

name: HAMLET
line: I shall in all my best obey you, madam.

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Why, 'tis a loving and a fair reply:

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Be as ourself in Denmark. Madam, come,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: This gentle and unforced accord of Hamlet

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Sits smiling to my heart: in grace whereof,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: No jocund health that Denmark drinks to-day,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: But the great cannon to the clouds shall tell,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: And the king's rouse the heavens all bruit again,

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Re-speaking earthly thunder. Come away.

name: KING CLAUDIUS
line: Exeunt all but HAMLET

name: HAMLET
line: O, that this too too solid flesh would melt

name: HAMLET
line: Thaw and resolve itself into a dew!

name: HAMLET
line: Or that the Everlasting had not fix'd

name: HAMLET
line: His canon 'gainst self-slaughter! O God! God!

name: HAMLET
line: How weary, stale, flat and unprofitable,

name: HAMLET
line: Seem to me all the uses of this world!

name: HAMLET
line: Fie on't! ah fie! 'tis an unweeded garden,

name: HAMLET
line: That grows to seed, things rank and gross in nature

name: HAMLET
line: Possess it merely. That it should come to this!

name: HAMLET
line: But two months dead: nay, not so much, not two:

name: HAMLET
line: So excellent a king, that was, to this,

name: HAMLET
line: Hyperion to a satyr, so loving to my mother

name: HAMLET
line: That he might not beteem the winds of heaven

name: HAMLET
line: Visit her face too roughly. Heaven and earth!

name: HAMLET
line: Must I remember? why, she would hang on him,

name: HAMLET
line: As if increase of appetite had grown

name: HAMLET
line: By what it fed on: and yet, within a month--

name: HAMLET
line: Let me not think on't--Frailty, thy name is woman!--

name: HAMLET
line: A little month, or ere those shoes were old

name: HAMLET
line: With which she follow'd my poor father's body,

name: HAMLET
line: Like Niobe, all tears:--why she, even she--

name: HAMLET
line: O, God! a beast, that wants discourse of reason,

name: HAMLET
line: Would have mourn'd longer--married with my uncle,

name: HAMLET
line: My father's brother, but no more like my father

name: HAMLET
line: Than I to Hercules: within a month:

name: HAMLET
line: Ere yet the salt of most unrighteous tears

name: HAMLET
line: Had left the flushing in her galled eyes,

name: HAMLET
line: She married. O, most wicked speed, to post

name: HAMLET
line: With such dexterity to incestuous sheets!

name: HAMLET
line: It is not nor it cannot come to good:

name: HAMLET
line: But break, my heart, for I must hold my tongue.

name: HAMLET
line: Enter HORATIO, MARCELLUS, and BERNARDO

name: HORATIO
line: Hail to your lordship!

name: HAMLET
line: I am glad to see you well:

name: HAMLET
line: Horatio,--or I do forget myself.

name: HORATIO
line: The same, my lord, and your poor servant ever.

name: HAMLET
line: Sir, my good friend, I'll change that name with you:

name: HAMLET
line: And what make you from Wittenberg, Horatio? Marcellus?

name: MARCELLUS
line: My good lord--

name: HAMLET
line: I am very glad to see you. Good even, sir.

name: HAMLET
line: But what, in faith, make you from Wittenberg?

name: HORATIO
line: A truant disposition, good my lord.

name: HAMLET
line: I would not hear your enemy say so,

name: HAMLET
line: Nor shall you do mine ear that violence,

name: HAMLET
line: To make it truster of your own report

name: HAMLET
line: Against yourself: I know you are no truant.

name: HAMLET
line: But what is your affair in Elsinore?

name: HAMLET
line: We'll teach you to drink deep ere you depart.

name: HORATIO
line: My lord, I came to see your father's funeral.

name: HAMLET
line: I pray thee, do not mock me, fellow-student,

name: HAMLET
line: I think it was to see my mother's wedding.

name: HORATIO
line: Indeed, my lord, it follow'd hard upon.

name: HAMLET
line: Thrift, thrift, Horatio! the funeral baked meats

name: HAMLET
line: Did coldly furnish forth the marriage tables.

name: HAMLET
line: Would I had met my dearest foe in heaven

name: HAMLET
line: Or ever I had seen that day, Horatio!

name: HAMLET
line: My father!--methinks I see my father.

name: HORATIO
line: Where, my lord?

name: HAMLET
line: In my mind's eye, Horatio.

name: HORATIO
line: I saw him once, he was a goodly king.

name: HAMLET
line: He was a man, take him for all in all,

name: HAMLET
line: I shall not look upon his like again.

name: HORATIO
line: My lord, I think I saw him yesternight.

name: HAMLET
line: Saw? who?

name: HORATIO
line: My lord, the king your father.

name: HAMLET
line: The king my father!

name: HORATIO
line: Season your admiration for awhile

name: HORATIO
line: With an attent ear, till I may deliver,

name: HORATIO
line: Upon the witness of these gentlemen,

name: HORATIO
line: This marvel to you.

name: HAMLET
line: For God's love, let me hear.

name: HORATIO
line: Two nights together had these gentlemen,

name: HORATIO
line: Marcellus and Bernardo, on their watch,

name: HORATIO
line: In the dead vast and middle of the night,

name: HORATIO
line: Been thus encounter'd. A figure like your father,

name: HORATIO
line: Armed at point exactly, cap-a-pe,

name: HORATIO
line: Appears before them, and with solemn march

name: HORATIO
line: Goes slow and stately by them: thrice he walk'd

name: HORATIO
line: By their oppress'd and fear-surprised eyes,

name: HORATIO
line: Within his truncheon's length, whilst they, distilled

name: HORATIO
line: Almost to jelly with the act of fear,

name: HORATIO
line: Stand dumb and speak not to him. This to me

name: HORATIO
line: In dreadful secrecy impart they did,

name: HORATIO
line: And I with them the third night kept the watch,

name: HORATIO
line: Where, as they had deliver'd, both in time,

name: HORATIO
line: Form of the thing, each word made true and good,

name: HORATIO
line: The apparition comes: I knew your father,

name: HORATIO
line: These hands are not more like.

name: HAMLET
line: But where was this?

name: MARCELLUS
line: My lord, upon the platform where we watch'd.

name: HAMLET
line: Did you not speak to it?

name: HORATIO
line: My lord, I did,

name: HORATIO
line: But answer made it none: yet once methought

name: HORATIO
line: It lifted up its head and did address

name: HORATIO
line: Itself to motion, like as it would speak,

name: HORATIO
line: But even then the morning cock crew loud,

name: HORATIO
line: And at the sound it shrunk in haste away,

name: HORATIO
line: And vanish'd from our sight.

name: HAMLET
line: 'Tis very strange.

name: HORATIO
line: As I do live, my honour'd lord, 'tis true,

name: HORATIO
line: And we did think it writ down in our duty

name: HORATIO
line: To let you know of it.

name: HAMLET
line: Indeed, indeed, sirs, but this troubles me.

name: HAMLET
line: Hold you the watch to-night?

name: BERNARDO
line: We do, my lord.

name: HAMLET
line: Arm'd, say you?

name: BERNARDO
line: Arm'd, my lord.

name: HAMLET
line: From top to toe?

name: BERNARDO
line: My lord, from head to foot.

name: HAMLET
line: Then saw you not his face?

name: HORATIO
line: O, yes, my lord, he wore his beaver up.

name: HAMLET
line: What, look'd he frowningly?

name: HORATIO
line: A countenance more in sorrow than in anger.

name: HAMLET
line: Pale or red?

name: HORATIO
line: Nay, very pale.

name: HAMLET
line: And fix'd his eyes upon you?

name: HORATIO
line: Most constantly.

name: HAMLET
line: I would I had been there.

name: HORATIO
line: It would have much amazed you.

name: HAMLET
line: Very like, very like. Stay'd it long?

name: HORATIO
line: While one with moderate haste might tell a hundred.

name: BERNARDO
line: Longer, longer.

name: HORATIO
line: Not when I saw't.

name: HAMLET
line: His beard was grizzled--no?

name: HORATIO
line: It was, as I have seen it in his life,

name: HORATIO
line: A sable silver'd.

name: HAMLET
line: I will watch to-night,

name: HAMLET
line: Perchance 'twill walk again.

name: HORATIO
line: I warrant it will.

name: HAMLET
line: If it assume my noble father's person,

name: HAMLET
line: I'll speak to it, though hell itself should gape

name: HAMLET
line: And bid me hold my peace. I pray you all,

name: HAMLET
line: If you have hitherto conceal'd this sight,

name: HAMLET
line: Let it be tenable in your silence still,

name: HAMLET
line: And whatsoever else shall hap to-night,

name: HAMLET
line: Give it an understanding, but no tongue:

name: HAMLET
line: I will requite your loves. So, fare you well:

name: HAMLET
line: Upon the platform, 'twixt eleven and twelve,

name: HAMLET
line: I'll visit you.

name: All
line: Our duty to your honour.

name: HAMLET
line: Your loves, as mine to you: farewell.

name: HAMLET
line: Exeunt all but HAMLET

name: HAMLET
line: My father's spirit in arms! all is not well,

name: HAMLET
line: I doubt some foul play: would the night were come!

name: HAMLET
line: Till then sit still, my soul: foul deeds will rise,

name: HAMLET
line: Though all the earth o'erwhelm them, to men's eyes.

name: HAMLET
line: Exit

name: HAMLET
line: SCENE III. A room in Polonius' house.

name: HAMLET
line: Enter LAERTES and OPHELIA

name: LAERTES
line: My necessaries are embark'd: farewell:

name: LAERTES
line: And, sister, as the winds give benefit

name: LAERTES
line: And convoy is assistant, do not sleep,

name: LAERTES
line: But let me hear from you.

name: OPHELIA
line: Do you doubt that?

name: LAERTES
line: For Hamlet and the trifling of his favour,

name: LAERTES
line: Hold it a fashion and a toy in blood,

name: LAERTES
line: A violet in the youth of primy nature,

name: LAERTES
line: Forward, not permanent, sweet, not lasting,

name: LAERTES
line: The perfume and suppliance of a minute, No more.

name: OPHELIA
line: No more but so?

name: LAERTES
line: Think it no more,

name: LAERTES
line: For nature, crescent, does not grow alone

name: LAERTES
line: In thews and bulk, but, as this temple waxes,

name: LAERTES
line: The inward service of the mind and soul

name: LAERTES
line: Grows wide withal. Perhaps he loves you now,

name: LAERTES
line: And now no soil nor cautel doth besmirch

name: LAERTES
line: The virtue of his will: but you must fear,

name: LAERTES
line: His greatness weigh'd, his will is not his own,

name: LAERTES
line: For he himself is subject to his birth:

name: LAERTES
line: He may not, as unvalued persons do,

name: LAERTES
line: Carve for himself, for on his choice depends

name: LAERTES
line: The safety and health of this whole state,

name: LAERTES
line: And therefore must his choice be circumscribed

name: LAERTES
line: Unto the voice and yielding of that body

name: LAERTES
line: Whereof he is the head. Then if he says he loves you,

name: LAERTES
line: It fits your wisdom so far to believe it

name: LAERTES
line: As he in his particular act and place

name: LAERTES
line: May give his saying deed, which is no further

name: LAERTES
line: Than the main voice of Denmark goes withal.

name: LAERTES
line: Then weigh what loss your honour may sustain,

name: LAERTES
line: If with too credent ear you list his songs,

name: LAERTES
line: Or lose your heart, or your chaste treasure open

name: LAERTES
line: To his unmaster'd importunity.

name: LAERTES
line: Fear it, Ophelia, fear it, my dear sister,

name: LAERTES
line: And keep you in the rear of your affection,

name: LAERTES
line: Out of the shot and danger of desire.

name: LAERTES
line: The chariest maid is prodigal enough,

name: LAERTES
line: If she unmask her beauty to the moon:

name: LAERTES
line: Virtue itself 'scapes not calumnious strokes:

name: LAERTES
line: The canker galls the infants of the spring,

name: LAERTES
line: Too oft before their buttons be disclosed,

name: LAERTES
line: And in the morn and liquid dew of youth

name: LAERTES
line: Contagious blastments are most imminent.

name: LAERTES
line: Be wary then, best safety lies in fear:

name: LAERTES
line: Youth to itself rebels, though none else near.

name: OPHELIA
line: I shall the effect of this good lesson keep,

name: OPHELIA
line: As watchman to my heart. But, good my brother,

name: OPHELIA
line: Do not, as some ungracious pastors do,

name: OPHELIA
line: Show me the steep and thorny way to heaven,

name: OPHELIA
line: Whiles, like a puff'd and reckless libertine,

name: OPHELIA
line: Himself the primrose path of dalliance treads,

name: OPHELIA
line: And recks not his own rede.

name: LAERTES
line: O, fear me not.

name: LAERTES
line: I stay too long: but here my father comes.

name: LAERTES
line: Enter POLONIUS

name: LAERTES
line: A double blessing is a double grace,

name: LAERTES
line: Occasion smiles upon a second leave.

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Yet here, Laertes! aboard, aboard, for shame!

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: The wind sits in the shoulder of your sail,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: And you are stay'd for. There, my blessing with thee!

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: And these few precepts in thy memory

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: See thou character. Give thy thoughts no tongue,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Nor any unproportioned thought his act.

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Be thou familiar, but by no means vulgar.

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Those friends thou hast, and their adoption tried,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Grapple them to thy soul with hoops of steel,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: But do not dull thy palm with entertainment

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Of each new-hatch'd, unfledged comrade. Beware

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Of entrance to a quarrel, but being in,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Bear't that the opposed may beware of thee.

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Give every man thy ear, but few thy voice,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Take each man's censure, but reserve thy judgment.

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Costly thy habit as thy purse can buy,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: But not express'd in fancy, rich, not gaudy,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: For the apparel oft proclaims the man,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: And they in France of the best rank and station

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Are of a most select and generous chief in that.

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Neither a borrower nor a lender be,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: For loan oft loses both itself and friend,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: And borrowing dulls the edge of husbandry.

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: This above all: to thine ownself be true,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: And it must follow, as the night the day,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Thou canst not then be false to any man.

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Farewell: my blessing season this in thee!

name: LAERTES
line: Most humbly do I take my leave, my lord.

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: The time invites you, go, your servants tend.

name: LAERTES
line: Farewell, Ophelia, and remember well

name: LAERTES
line: What I have said to you.

name: OPHELIA
line: 'Tis in my memory lock'd,

name: OPHELIA
line: And you yourself shall keep the key of it.

name: LAERTES
line: Farewell.

name: LAERTES
line: Exit

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: What is't, Ophelia, be hath said to you?

name: OPHELIA
line: So please you, something touching the Lord Hamlet.

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Marry, well bethought:

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: 'Tis told me, he hath very oft of late

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Given private time to you, and you yourself

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Have of your audience been most free and bounteous:

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: If it be so, as so 'tis put on me,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: And that in way of caution, I must tell you,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: You do not understand yourself so clearly

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: As it behoves my daughter and your honour.

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: What is between you? give me up the truth.

name: OPHELIA
line: He hath, my lord, of late made many tenders

name: OPHELIA
line: Of his affection to me.

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Affection! pooh! you speak like a green girl,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Unsifted in such perilous circumstance.

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Do you believe his tenders, as you call them?

name: OPHELIA
line: I do not know, my lord, what I should think.

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Marry, I'll teach you: think yourself a baby,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: That you have ta'en these tenders for true pay,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Which are not sterling. Tender yourself more dearly,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Or--not to crack the wind of the poor phrase,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Running it thus--you'll tender me a fool.

name: OPHELIA
line: My lord, he hath importuned me with love

name: OPHELIA
line: In honourable fashion.

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Ay, fashion you may call it, go to, go to.

name: OPHELIA
line: And hath given countenance to his speech, my lord,

name: OPHELIA
line: With almost all the holy vows of heaven.

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Ay, springes to catch woodcocks. I do know,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: When the blood burns, how prodigal the soul

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Lends the tongue vows: these blazes, daughter,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Giving more light than heat, extinct in both,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Even in their promise, as it is a-making,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: You must not take for fire. From this time

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Be somewhat scanter of your maiden presence,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Set your entreatments at a higher rate

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Than a command to parley. For Lord Hamlet,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Believe so much in him, that he is young

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: And with a larger tether may he walk

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Than may be given you: in few, Ophelia,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Do not believe his vows, for they are brokers,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Not of that dye which their investments show,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: But mere implorators of unholy suits,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Breathing like sanctified and pious bawds,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: The better to beguile. This is for all:

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: I would not, in plain terms, from this time forth,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Have you so slander any moment leisure,

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: As to give words or talk with the Lord Hamlet.

name: LORD POLONIUS
line: Look to't, I charge you: come your ways.

name: OPHELIA
line: I shall obey, my lord.

name: OPHELIA
line: Exeunt

name: OPHELIA
line: SCENE IV. The platform.

name: OPHELIA
line: Enter HAMLET, HORATIO, and MARCELLUS

name: HAMLET
line: The air bites shrewdly, it is very cold.

name: HORATIO
line: It is a nipping and an eager air.

name: HAMLET
line: What hour now?

name: HORATIO
line: I think it lacks of twelve.

name: HAMLET
line: No, it is struck.

name: HORATIO
line: Indeed? I heard it not: then it draws near the season

name: HORATIO
line: Wherein the spirit held his wont to walk.

name: HORATIO
line: A flourish of trumpets, and ordnance shot off, within

name: HORATIO
line: What does this mean, my lord?

name: HAMLET
line: The king doth wake to-night and takes his rouse,

name: HAMLET
line: Keeps wassail, and the swaggering up-spring reels,

name: HAMLET
line: And, as he drains his draughts of Rhenish down,

name: HAMLET
line: The kettle-drum and trumpet thus bray out

name: HAMLET
line: The triumph of his pledge.

name: HORATIO
line: Is it a custom?

name: HAMLET
line: Ay, marry, is't:

name: HAMLET
line: But to my mind, though I am native here

name: HAMLET
line: And to the manner born, it is a custom

name: HAMLET
line: More honour'd in the breach than the observance.

name: HAMLET
line: This heavy-headed revel east and west

name: HAMLET
line: Makes us traduced and tax'd of other nations:

name: HAMLET
line: They clepe us drunkards, and with swinish phrase

name: HAMLET
line: Soil our addition, and indeed it takes

name: HAMLET
line: From our achievements, though perform'd at height,

name: HAMLET
line: The pith and marrow of our attribute.

name: HAMLET
line: So, oft it chances in particular men,

name: HAMLET
line: That for some vicious mole of nature in them,

name: HAMLET
line: As, in their birth--wherein they are not guilty,

name: HAMLET
line: Since nature cannot choose his origin--

name: HAMLET
line: By the o'ergrowth of some complexion,

name: HAMLET
line: Oft breaking down the pales and forts of reason,

name: HAMLET
line: Or by some habit that too much o'er-leavens

name: HAMLET
line: The form of plausive manners, that these men,

name: HAMLET
line: Carrying, I say, the stamp of one defect,

name: HAMLET
line: Being nature's livery, or fortune's star,--

name: HAMLET
line: Their virtues else--be they as pure as grace,

name: HAMLET
line: As infinite as man may undergo--

name: HAMLET
line: Shall in the general censure take corruption

name: HAMLET
line: From that particular fault: the dram of eale

name: HAMLET
line: Doth all the noble substance of a doubt

name: HAMLET
line: To his own scandal.

name: HORATIO
line: Look, my lord, it comes!

name: HORATIO
line: Enter Ghost

name: HAMLET
line: Angels and ministers of grace defend us!

name: HAMLET
line: Be thou a spirit of health or goblin damn'd,

name: HAMLET
line: Bring with thee airs from heaven or blasts from hell,

name: HAMLET
line: Be thy intents wicked or charitable,

name: HAMLET
line: Thou comest in such a questionable shape

name: HAMLET
line: That I will speak to thee: I'll call thee Hamlet,

name: HAMLET
line: King, father, royal Dane: O, answer me!

name: HAMLET
line: Let me not burst in ignorance, but tell

name: HAMLET
line: Why thy canonized bones, hearsed in death,

name: HAMLET
line: Have burst their cerements, why the sepulchre,

name: HAMLET
line: Wherein we saw thee quietly inurn'd,

name: HAMLET
line: Hath oped his ponderous and marble jaws,

name: HAMLET
line: To cast thee up again. What may this mean,

name: HAMLET
line: That thou, dead corse, again in complete steel

name: HAMLET
line: Revisit'st thus the glimpses of the moon,

name: HAMLET
line: Making night hideous, and we fools of nature

name: HAMLET
line: So horridly to shake our disposition

name: HAMLET
line: With thoughts beyond the reaches of our souls?

name: HAMLET
line: Say, why is this? wherefore? what should we do?

name: HAMLET
line: Ghost beckons HAMLET

name: HORATIO
line: It beckons you to go away with it,

name: HORATIO
line: As if it some impartment did desire

name: HORATIO
line: To you alone.

name: MARCELLUS
line: Look, with what courteous action

name: MARCELLUS
line: It waves you to a more removed ground:

name: MARCELLUS
line: But do not go with it.

name: HORATIO
line: No, by no means.

name: HAMLET
line: It will not speak, then I will follow it.

name: HORATIO
line: Do not, my lord.

name: HAMLET
line: Why, what should be the fear?

name: HAMLET
line: I do not set my life in a pin's fee,

name: HAMLET
line: And for my soul, what can it do to that,

name: HAMLET
line: Being a thing immortal as itself?

name: HAMLET
line: It waves me forth again: I'll follow it.

name: HORATIO
line: What if it tempt you toward the flood, my lord,

name: HORATIO
line: Or to the dreadful summit of the cliff

name: HORATIO
line: That beetles o'er his base into the sea,

name: HORATIO
line: And there assume some other horrible form,

name: HORATIO
line: Which might deprive your sovereignty of reason

name: HORATIO
line: And draw you into madness? think of it:

name: HORATIO
line: The very place puts toys of desperation,

name: HORATIO
line: Without more motive, into every brain

name: HORATIO
line: That looks so many fathoms to the sea

name: HORATIO
line: And hears it roar beneath.

name: HAMLET
line: It waves me still.

name: HAMLET
line: Go on, I'll follow thee.

name: MARCELLUS
line: You shall not go, my lord.

name: HAMLET
line: Hold off your hands.

name: HORATIO
line: Be ruled, you shall not go.

name: HAMLET
line: My fate cries out,

name: HAMLET
line: And makes each petty artery in this body

name: HAMLET
line: As hardy as the Nemean lion's nerve.

name: HAMLET
line: Still am I call'd. Unhand me, gentlemen.

name: HAMLET
line: By heaven, I'll make a ghost of him that lets me!

name: HAMLET
line: I say, away! Go on, I'll follow thee.

name: HAMLET
line: Exeunt Ghost and HAMLET

name: HORATIO
line: He waxes desperate with imagination.

name: MARCELLUS
line: Let's follow, 'tis not fit thus to obey him.

name: HORATIO
line: Have after. To what issue will this come?

name: MARCELLUS
line: Something is rotten in the state of Denmark.

name: HORATIO
line: Heaven will direct it.

name: MARCELLUS
line: Nay, let's follow him.

name: MARCELLUS
line: Exeunt

name: MARCELLUS
line: SCENE V. Another part of the platform.

name: MARCELLUS
line: Enter GHOST and HAMLET

name: HAMLET
line: Where wilt thou lead me? speak, I'll go no further.

name: Ghost
line: Mark me.

name: HAMLET
line: I will.

name: Ghost
line: My hour is almost come,

name: Ghost
line: When I to sulphurous and tormenting flames

name: Ghost
line: Must render up myself.

name: HAMLET
line: Alas, poor ghost!

name: Ghost
line: Pity me not, but lend thy serious hearing

name: Ghost
line: To what I shall unfold.

name: HAMLET
line: Speak, I am bound to hear.

name: Ghost
line: So art thou to revenge, when thou shalt hear.

name: HAMLET
line: What?

name: Ghost
line: I am thy father's spirit,

name: Ghost
line: Doom'd for a certain term to walk the night,

name: Ghost
line: And for the day confined to fast in fires,

name: Ghost
line: Till the foul crimes done in my days of nature

name: Ghost
line: Are burnt and purged away. But that I am forbid

name: Ghost
line: To tell the secrets of my prison-house,

name: Ghost
line: I could a tale unfold whose lightest word

name: Ghost
line: Would harrow up thy soul, freeze thy young blood,

name: Ghost
line: Make thy two eyes, like stars, start from their spheres,

name: Ghost
line: Thy knotted and combined locks to part

name: Ghost
line: And each particular hair to stand on end,

name: Ghost
line: Like quills upon the fretful porpentine:

name: Ghost
line: But this eternal blazon must not be

name: Ghost
line: To ears of flesh and blood. List, list, O, list!

name: Ghost
line: If thou didst ever thy dear father love--

name: HAMLET
line: O God!

name: Ghost
line: Revenge his foul and most unnatural murder.

name: HAMLET
line: Murder!

name: Ghost
line: Murder most foul, as in the best it is,

name: Ghost
line: But this most foul, strange and unnatural.

name: HAMLET
line: Haste me to know't, that I, with wings as swift

name: HAMLET
line: As meditation or the thoughts of love,

name: HAMLET
line: May sweep to my revenge.

name: Ghost
line: I find thee apt,

name: Ghost
line: And duller shouldst thou be than the fat weed

name: Ghost
line: That roots itself in ease on Lethe wharf,

name: Ghost
line: Wouldst thou not stir in this. Now, Hamlet, hear:

name: Ghost
line: 'Tis given out that, sleeping in my orchard,

name: Ghost
line: A serpent stung me, so the whole ear of Denmark

name: Ghost
line: Is by a forged process of my death

name: Ghost
line: Rankly abused: but know, thou noble youth,

name: Ghost
line: The serpent that did sting thy father's life

name: Ghost
line: Now wears his crown.

name: HAMLET
line: O my prophetic soul! My uncle!

name: Ghost
line: Ay, that incestuous, that adulterate beast,

name: Ghost
line: With witchcraft of his wit, with traitorous gifts,--

name: Ghost
line: O wicked wit and gifts, that have the power

name: Ghost
line: So to seduce!--won to his shameful lust

name: Ghost
line: The will of my most seeming-virtuous queen:

name: Ghost
line: O Hamlet, what a falling-off was there!

name: Ghost
line: From me, whose love was of that dignity

name: Ghost
line: That it went hand in hand even with the vow

name: Ghost
line: I made to her in marriage, and to decline

name: Ghost
line: Upon a wretch whose natural gifts were poor

name: Ghost
line: To those of mine!

name: Ghost
line: But virtue, as it never will be moved,

name: Ghost
line: Though lewdness court it in a shape of heaven,

name: Ghost
line: So lust, though to a radiant angel link'd,

name: Ghost
line: Will sate itself in a celestial bed,

name: Ghost
line: And prey on garbage.

name: Ghost
line: But, soft! methinks I scent the morning air,

name: Ghost
line: Brief let me be. Sleeping within my orchard,

name: Ghost
line: My custom always of the afternoon,

name: Ghost
line: Upon my secure hour thy uncle stole,

name: Ghost
line: With juice of cursed hebenon in a vial,

name: Ghost
line: And in the porches of my ears did pour

name: Ghost
line: The leperous distilment, whose effect

name: Ghost
line: Holds such an enmity with blood of man

name: Ghost
line: That swift as quicksilver it courses through

name: Ghost
line: The natural gates and alleys of the body,

name: Ghost
line: And with a sudden vigour doth posset

name: Ghost
line: And curd, like eager droppings into milk,

name: Ghost
line: The thin and wholesome blood: so did it mine,

name: Ghost
line: And a most instant tetter bark'd about,

name: Ghost
line: Most lazar-like, with vile and loathsome crust,

name: Ghost
line: All my smooth body.

name: Ghost
line: Thus was I, sleeping, by a brother's hand

name: Ghost
line: Of life, of crown, of queen, at once dispatch'd:

name: Ghost
line: Cut off even in the blossoms of my sin,

name: Ghost
line: Unhousel'd, disappointed, unanel'd,

name: Ghost
line: No reckoning made, but sent to my account

name: Ghost
line: With all my imperfections on my head:

name: Ghost
line: O, horrible! O, horrible! most horrible!

name: Ghost
line: If thou hast nature in thee, bear it not,

name: Ghost
line: Let not the royal bed of Denmark be

name: Ghost
line: A couch for luxury and damned incest.

name: Ghost
line: But, howsoever thou pursuest this act,

name: Ghost
line: Taint not thy mind, nor let thy soul contrive

name: Ghost
line: Against thy mother aught: leave her to heaven

name: Ghost
line: And to those thorns that in her bosom lodge,

name: Ghost
line: To prick and sting her. Fare thee well at once!

name: Ghost
line: The glow-worm shows the matin to be near,

name: Ghost
line: And 'gins to pale his uneffectual fire:

name: Ghost
line: Adieu, adieu! Hamlet, remember me.

name: Ghost
line: Exit

name: HAMLET

name: HAMLET

name: HAMLET
line: O most pernicious woman!

name: HAMLET

name: HAMLET
line: My tables,--meet it is I set it down,

name: HAMLET

name: HAMLET
line: Writing

name: HAMLET

name: HAMLET

name: HORATIO

name: HORATIO
line: In faith,

name: HORATIO

name: HAMLET

name: LORD POLONIUS

name: REYNALDO
